vote.title: Keeping Schools and Communities Safe and Supported in Response to Noxious Odor Near Dominguez Channel (Res-012-21/22) (Waiver of Board Rule 72)
vote.description: Whereas, For over three weeks since October 7, 2021, our students and families of Carson and neighboring cities have been deeply impacted by an odorous nuisance connected to the Dominguez Channel;Whereas, As of October 19th, Los Angeles County public health officials advised residents to avoid prolonged outdoor exercise in the late evening or early morning hours due to the continuing presence of hydrogen sulfide in the community;Whereas, Carson residents reported impacts of the odor, including dizziness, headaches, eye and throat irritation, nausea, nose bleeds, ear infections, stomach aches, vomiting, and other similar symptoms of hydrogen sulfide exposure;Whereas, 40 students are known to have relocated, 42 students are known to have been absent, over half of schools in Carson Community of School have had to use an “inclement schedule,” with Towne Avenue having to for 14 days, as a result of the issue;Whereas, The Los Angeles Unified School District Office of Environmental Health and Safety continues to monitor the situation and work with Los Angeles County and the South Coast Air Quality Management District to measure air quality every day, in the community and at schools, and take proactive steps to ensure the safety of our students and school staff, including keeping students indoors when most impacted by the smell;Whereas, There needs to be a proactive plan developed and commitment from the appropriate governmental agencies to pursue a more urgent and equitable approach to climate change, including restoring the Dominguez Channel to a healthy estuary;Whereas, For too long our most vulnerable communities have been negatively impacted by environmental injustices that exacerbate health and racial disparities and impact quality of life;Whereas, Our communities and the families we serve expect and deserve a timely response from governmental agencies to address their concerns;Whereas, Los Angeles County has received 3,000 complaints and 2,900 reimbursement requests and the City of Carson has received 3,000 complaints; andWhereas, On October 26, 2021, the Carson City Council, under the leadership of Carson Mayor Lula Davis-Holmes, ratified the declaration of a local emergency, as defined in the California Government Code §8558(c), and Carson Municipal Code §3705, requested the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors and Governor follow suit, and called on all agencies to expedite processes needed for immediate cleanup and restoration of the channel; andWhereas, On November 2, 2021, Los Angeles County Board of Supervisor Holly Mitchell introduced a motion to proclaim a local emergency for the Dominguez Channel Odor event, allowing the County to maximize resources from all levels of government and the motion was unanimously approved; now, therefore, be itResolved, That the Governing Board of the Los Angeles Unified School District stands in agreement with the decision of the City of Carson and the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors to declare a local emergency and call on the Governor to do the same in response to the odorous nuisance near the Dominguez Channel; and, be it finallyResolved, That the District commits to take all necessary steps to maintain the safety, health and wellness for all students, staff and schools in the Carson Community of Schools and surrounding Community of Schools, including assessing and responding to the impact of this event on students and staff who may have relocated or may have missed school.
